headline: Fire Kills 13 Monkeys at U.K. Safari Park
abstract: Recent weeks have brought bad news for zoos in London and Berlin and a safari park in England.

headline: Bank of America Executive Departs After Misconduct Claim
abstract: The executive, Omeed Malik, was accused of inappropriate sexual conduct with a young woman, according to people briefed on the bank’s investigation.

headline: Prosecutors Investigate Firms That Offer Plaintiffs Early Cash
abstract: The federal authorities are looking into the relationship between trial lawyers and companies that provide high-interest advances on settlements or jury awards.

headline: H&M Apologizes for ‘Monkey’ Image Featuring Black Child
abstract: The retailer said it would no longer sell the shirt shown in the image, which appeared to refer to a black child as the “coolest monkey in the jungle.”

headline: Korean War, a ‘Forgotten’ Conflict That Shaped the Modern World
abstract: The three-year conflict set the stage for decades of tension on the Korean Peninsula, but today many Americans know little about it.

headline: Why It’s So Hard to Invest With a Social Conscience
abstract: Want guns out of your stock portfolio? Sick of bad actors like Wells Fargo and Equifax? You’ll face at least seven challenges when making an investing plan.

headline: With a Tax Deduction Gone, Is Home Equity a Smart Way to Pay for College?
abstract: The new tax law removes the ability to deduct interest paid on home equity loans. Will schools ask less of families, and should parents even use the loans to pay for school?

headline: You Can’t Fire Equifax, but Your Employer Can. Mine Just Did.
abstract: After Equifax’s security breach, consumers looked for ways to make the company pay. One option: Persuade employers not to give the company any data.

headline: One State’s Quest to Introduce Long-Term Care Benefits
abstract: A bipartisan effort to tax Washington workers and offer a year of nursing home or other coverage is mired in questions over caregiver qualifications.

headline: Bitcoin Falls Below $10,000 as Virtual Currency Bubble Deflates
abstract: The price of one Bitcoin is down 50 percent from its peak as concerns grow that governments may crack down on virtual currency trading.

headline: ‘Gloomy.’ ‘Amazing.’ Trump’s Speech Divides the Pundits.
abstract: After the ‘most tweeted’ State of the Union speech ever, Megyn Kelly and Chris Christie try out new roles, and Van Jones comes out swinging.

headline: Breitbart, Facing Headwinds, Tries a New Tack: Live Events
abstract: The right-wing website is taking a cue from one of its foes — the mainstream media — and sponsoring a town-hall event in suburban New Orleans next month.

headline: Comedian Going to White House Correspondents’ Dinner. What About Trump?
abstract: Michelle Wolf, a stand-up comic and contributor to “The Daily Show with Trevor Noah,” takes on one of the most prominent — and perilous — gigs in comedy.

headline: Fox News Analyst Quits, Calling Network a ‘Propaganda Machine’
abstract: Ralph Peters, a retired lieutenant colonel, sent an email to his colleagues saying he was “ashamed” of what the channel had become.

headline: Graydon Carter, Ex-Editor of Vanity Fair, Invests in an App
abstract: The music producer Quincy Jones and the mogul Ron Meyer join Mr. Carter, who is now on ‘garden leave,’ in investing in an Instagram-style app called Zig.

headline: After Donald Trump Said It, How News Outlets Handled It
abstract: Media outlets took the unusual step of allowing a vulgar word in print and on air after a report that Mr. Trump had used the term to describe African nations and Haiti.

headline: In Age of Trump, Political Reporters Are in Demand and Under Attack
abstract: White House correspondents have plenty of material — and plenty of angst — as they cover what Stephen K. Bannon calls “the first McLuhanesque presidency.”

headline: What He Did on His Summer Break: Exposed a Global Security Flaw
abstract: Nathan Ruser, an Australian college student, discovered that a fitness app revealed the locations of military sites around the world. Now he has to decide what he’s doing after graduation.

headline: As Gay Australians Hear Wedding Bells, Vendors See Dollar Signs
abstract: One analyst estimates that same-sex marriage could provide a 650 million Australian dollar boost to the economy in 12 months.

headline: Barnaby Joyce, Australian Politician at Center of Sex Scandal, Defies Pressure to Quit
abstract: Mr. Joyce, who leads the junior party in the coalition government, said Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull’s criticism of him had been “inept” and “unnecessary.”

headline: Big and Small, N.R.A. Boycott Efforts Come Together in Gun Debate
abstract: From individual Twitter posts to orchestrated efforts by advocacy groups, the protests against the gun lobby have coalesced into a powerful movement.

headline: Trump Rollbacks Target Offshore Rules ‘Written With Human Blood’
abstract: Drillers seek to gain from an easing of Obama-era safety and environmental regulations that were adopted after the Deepwater Horizon disaster killed 11 people.

headline: President or Luxury Towers: Either Way, Trump Is the Rage in India
abstract: President Trump’s eldest son is headed to India on a sales trip for the family’s real estate business. Indians are star-struck by a family both rich and famous.

headline: Delta Air Lines Tightens Rules for Service and Support Animals
abstract: The carrier will require more preflight documentation as a surge in animals used to aid disabled travelers and offer emotional support has raised safety concerns.

headline: University Pulls Back on Pollution Study That Supported Its Benefactor
abstract: The president of Tennessee Technological University wrote to the E.P.A. saying the accuracy of the emissions study had been called into question.

headline: Nike Executive Resigns; C.E.O. Addresses Workplace Behavior Complaints
abstract: Trevor Edwards will step down as brand president. He was seen as a potential successor to the chief executive, Mark Parker, who informed workers about reports of misbehavior at Nike.

headline: In N.R.A. Fight, Delta Finds There Is No Neutral Ground
abstract: A conservative backlash highlighted the challenge confronting corporations that are struggling to cater to both ends of America’s political and cultural poles.

headline: Toys ‘R’ Us Customers Lament Store Closings: ‘I Want to Cry Right Now’
abstract: Before the age of buying with a click, generations knew there was a place where they could let their wishes whir.

headline: When Mortal Kombat Came Under Congressional Scrutiny
abstract: Violence in video games have been fodder for politicians for decades. Politicians from both sides of the aisle have found them a useful target.

headline: Why It May Be Impossible to Measure the Impact of Stores Limiting Gun Sales
abstract: Major retailers have pledged to stop selling certain assault-style rifles and raise age requirements. But the potential effects are difficult to discern because sales data is limited.

headline: At Retail Trade Show, Technology Is the Star
abstract: The National Retail Federation expo resembles the electronics trade show CES, fixating on artificial intelligence, big data and automation.

headline: Wynn Resorts Will Not Pay Steve Wynn Severance
abstract: Mr. Wynn, who founded the casino company, will forgo up to $330 million in separation compensation and agreed to a two-year noncompete clause.

headline: Tourist From New York Is Arrested in Japan as Woman’s Body Parts Are Found
abstract: The man was being interrogated about the woman’s disappearance when he provided information that led to the grisly discoveries, the police told Japanese news media.

headline: Populism Is Waning, Which Is Reason to Party in Davos
abstract: As the World Economic Forum convenes in Davos, the powerful are feeling optimistic because of waning worries about populism and global economic growth.

headline: Gay Mardi Gras in Sydney Goes Corporate, Clashing With Activist Roots
abstract: The inclusion of more corporations in a festival sometimes comes at the expense of grass-roots activists and longtime participants.

headline: Streaming Soon: A Fight Over AT&T, Time Warner, and the Future of TV
abstract: The Justice Department’s case to block AT&T’s $85 billion merger with Time Warner is set for trial next week, in one of the most anticipated antitrust battles in years.

headline: House Passes Online Sex-Trafficking Bill After Big Tech Companies Back Off
abstract: Silicon Valley had strongly opposed the bill because it chips away at an existing law that gives internet companies broad immunity.

headline: Why Companies and Countries Are Battling for Ascendancy in 5G
abstract: Taking an early lead in ultrafast next-generation wireless technology can give players a strategic advantage.

headline: AT&T Is Said to Want Antitrust Official on Witness List for Trial
abstract: The company is requesting that Makan Delrahim testify in the trial over the government’s decision to block its merger with Time Warner, sources said.

headline: Turner Chief Pushes Back on Core Justice Dept. Argument
abstract: John Martin, the chief executive of Turner, told a federal court that his channels were not absolutely vital for a cable or satellite business.

headline: Trump Blocks Broadcom’s Bid for Qualcomm
abstract: President Trump issued an order prohibiting Broadcom, a Singapore-based chip maker, from purchasing Qualcomm, citing a threat to the national security of the United States.

headline: F.C.C. Watchdog Looks Into Changes That Benefited Sinclair
abstract: An investigation could lead to questions that the F.C.C. chairman, Ajit Pai, has so far tried to avoid answering in public.

headline: Hong Kong Moves to Ban All Ivory Sales, Closing a Loophole
abstract: The city had long permitted the sale of antique ivory, which activists said ultimately created an incentive for poaching.

headline: Court Overturns Obama-Era Rule on Retirement Planners
abstract: A federal appeals court ruled that the Labor Department overstepped its authority in requiring financial professionals to act in their clients’ best interests.

headline: Loan Program Plans to Offer Students Prepaid Bank Cards
abstract: The cards would hold loan amounts that exceeded tuition, giving borrowers another way to pay expenses — and financial firms a peek at spending patterns.

headline: New Service, Same Old Equifax: Credit Locking App Freezes Up
abstract: After a major breach last year, the credit rating agency promised an app that would make it easy — and free — to lock your credit. It didn’t work.

headline: When Trading in Bitcoin, Keep the Tax Man in Mind
abstract: The virtual currency has enjoyed a spectacular rise in value, but there are important tax implications. Here’s a guide.

headline: On Social Media, Lax Enforcement Lets Impostor Accounts Thrive
abstract: Millions of “bots” posing as real users are promoting celebrities, spreading misinformation and sowing discord. And it’s far easier to build a bot than to kill one.

headline: Jeff Bezos, Mr. Amazon, Steps Out
abstract: Mr. Bezos is the world’s richest person and can afford virtually any luxury. But obscurity is no longer among them.

headline: U.K. Appoints a Minister for Loneliness
abstract: Prime Minister Theresa May said an under secretary would work across government departments to tackle the issue.

headline: Trump Moves to Greatly Expand Offshore Drilling: DealBook Briefing
abstract: The Trump administration will allow new offshore oil and gas drilling in nearly all United States waters, a move likely welcomed by the energy industry.

headline: Peter Thiel Is a Bitcoin Believer: DealBook Briefing
abstract: The value of the digital currency jumped this afternoon after Mr. Thiel’s Founders Fund venture firm emerged as an investor.

headline: New Facebook Should Benefit Investors Long Term: DealBook Briefing
abstract: Mark Zuckerberg’s return to focusing more on their welfare of Facebook’s users may limit short-run profits but should improve sustainability.

headline: Mnuchin Takes on the Dollar at Davos: DealBook Briefing
abstract: The Treasury secretary’s advocacy for a weak dollar heightened the sense of conflict between the U.S. and other countries at the World Economic Forum.

headline: Stocks Record Their Biggest Two-Day Rally Since 2016: DealBook Briefing
abstract: Stocks on Wall Street endured their worst week in two years last week. Monday they capped their biggest two-day advance since 2016.

headline: Spotify Is Getting Paid to Save the Music Industry: DealBook Briefing
abstract: Spotify has revived the fortunes of recording artists, funneling billions of dollars to music companies. But a charity Spotify is not.

headline: Tallying Wells Fargo’s Penalties: DealBook Briefing
abstract: The pending replacement of four directors is only the latest in a series of punishments that the bank has taken for its lending practices.

headline: Comcast Leaves Fox With Few Good Options: DealBook Briefing
abstract: Fox can either revise the terms of the Disney sale to exclude Sky, or enter into a bidding war with Comcast. Neither option is appealing.

headline: Stocks Enter Correction Territory: DealBook Briefing
abstract: The Dow and S.&P. 500 fell Thursday into correction territory for the first time in two years.

headline: Can Deutsche Bank Be Fixed?: DealBook Briefing
abstract: Imagine you are applying to be the C.E.O. of Deutsche Bank now that it’s reportedly seeking a successor to John Cryan. What would you do first?

headline: More Than Just a Sell-Off in Tech?: DealBook Briefing
abstract: Investors spent the last three years piling into the shares of the biggest tech companies. Now the intellectual underpinnings of the tech rally are being seriously tested.

headline: Who’s Still in Amazon’s HQ2 Contest: DealBook Briefing
abstract: New York, Boston and Dallas are still vying to host Amazon’s second headquarters. But Detroit is out of the running.
